meta.description: Educational content for SGBs, Corporate Bonds, G-Secs, and 54EC Bonds focusing on YTM, liquidity risks, and taxation.

sgb_knowledge.title: Sovereign Gold Bonds (SGB): The Gold Standard

benefits_decoder.name: Tax-Free Maturity
benefits_decoder.insight: Unlike physical gold or Gold ETFs, the capital gains on SGBs are completely tax-free if held until maturity (8 years).
benefits_decoder.action: Always prefer SGB over physical coins for investment.

benefits_decoder.name: The Extra 2.5%
benefits_decoder.insight: You earn 2.5% simple interest per year on your initial investment amount, paid semi-annually. This is fully taxable.
benefits_decoder.action: Factor this into your cash flow, but remember it's taxable income.

liquidity_check.insight: You can surrender the bond to RBI after 5 years on interest payment dates. However, you can sell on the stock exchange anytime if you have a Demat account (liquidity may be low).
liquidity_check.action: Check exchange prices; SGBs often trade at a discount to gold prices in the secondary market.

risk_decoder.name: Coupon Rate vs YTM
risk_decoder.insight: A bond might have a 10% Coupon (Interest Rate) but trade at ₹1,100 (Face Value ₹1,000). Your actual return (YTM) will be much lower than 10% because you lose ₹100 capital at maturity.
risk_decoder.action: Always look at 'Yield to Maturity' (YTM), NEVER just the Coupon Rate.

risk_decoder.name: Credit Rating Reality
risk_decoder.insight: AAA is safest, but AA or A rated bonds offer higher rates. Remember, if a company defaults (like DHFL/IL&FS), you can lose 100% principal.
risk_decoder.action: For retail investors, stick to AAA or AA+ rated bonds only.

risk_decoder.name: Liquidity Risk
risk_decoder.insight: Unlike stocks, retail bonds in India have very low trading volume. You might not find a buyer when you want to sell before maturity.
risk_decoder.action: Only invest money you can afford to lock away until the maturity date.

structure_check.reason: Secured bonds are backed by company assets. If they go bankrupt, assets are sold to pay you. Unsecured bonds (or Perpetual/AT1 bonds) have no such guarantee.
structure_check.action: Check the Information Memorandum (IM) to see if it is 'Secured'.

features.name: Save LTCG Tax
features.insight: If you sell property and have Long Term Capital Gains, investing that gain (up to ₹50 Lakh) in 54EC bonds (REC/PFC/IRFC) within 6 months saves the tax.
features.action: Strict 6-month deadline from date of property sale.

features.name: Low Returns (5.25%)
features.insight: These bonds pay very low interest (~5.25%), which is taxable. The only benefit is saving the 12.5% or 20% tax on your property profit.
features.action: Calculate: Is saving 12.5% tax worth locking money at 5% for 5 years? (Usually yes, but check math).

rules.name: Interest Income
rules.insight: Interest from Corporate Bonds, G-Secs, and 54EC is added to your income and taxed at your slab rate (10%/20%/30%).
rules.exception: Only Tax-Free Bonds (issued by PSUs like NHAI/HUDCO years ago) have tax-free interest.

rules.name: Selling Before Maturity
rules.insight: If you sell a listed bond on the exchange after holding for 12 months, profit is taxed at 12.5%. If sold before 12 months, it is slab rate.
rules.action: Holding > 1 year is tax-efficient for listed bonds.
